titlestmt.titleproper: José Emilio Pacheco Papers, circa 1940s-2010s: Finding Aid C1619
titlestmt.author: Armando Suárez

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-09-02 10:10:32 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid content adheres to that prescribed by Describing Archives: A Content Standard."

did.abstract: Consists of the papers (circa 1940s-2010s) of Mexican poet, essayist, novelist and short story writer, José Emilio Pacheco. Materials include notebooks, diaries and journals, writings, correspondence, printed materials, and other items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of José Emilio Pacheco's handwritten notebooks, in which Pacheco appears to have recorded draft iterations of his writings, miscellaneous notes, and other information related to his creative process; diaries and journals containing handwritten dated entries; writings, such as drafts, excerpts, addenda, and final versions, including poetry, short stories, scripts, screenplays, essays, articles, and translations; a few writings by others; correspondence from various colleagues, publishers, family, and friends, including Octavio Paz, Juan Vicente Melo, Carlos Fuentes, José Miguel Oviedo, Sergio Galindo, Bruno Arcudi, Félix Grande, Guillermo Cabrera Infante, Homero Aridjis, Carlos Monsivaís, Rosario Castellanos, José Bianco, and Vicente Rojo; printed materials, including periodicals, newspaper clippings, articles, publications, and broadsides; and other materials, including photographs, biographical documents, certificates, and materials related to awards given to Pacheco.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: As no original order was discernible, materials were arranged in file groups by type of materials. Additionally, a large number of the writings were undated, untitled, unattributed, and in many cases, drafts and fragments mixed together, which were impossible to separate and identify given the disorganized state of the material upon receipt.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The majority of the collection is open for research. Materials in the "Diaries and Journals" series (boxes B-001261 to B-001268) are restricted for a period of five years, until April 2024, as requested by Cristina Pacheco.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Inquiries regarding publishing material from the collection should be directed to RBSC Public Services staff through the Ask Us! form. The library has no information on the status of literary rights in the collection and researchers are responsible for determining any questions of copyright.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: No materials were removed from the collection during 2019 processing beyond routine appraisal practices.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Armando Suárez in April 2019. Finding aid written by Armando Suárez in April 2019

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials in this collection, particularly materials from: Box B-001275, Folder 1, were treated for mold during April 2019 processing.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: José Emilio Pacheco was a poet, essayist, novelist and short story writer. He was born in Mexico City on June 30, 1939. Pacheco attended the National Autonomous University of Mexico, where he studied law and literature and worked for literary publications but did not earn a degree. He later taught at various universities in Mexico, United States, Canada, and England, including the University of Maryland at College Park, and the University of Essex, England. Pacheco also worked as director and editor of various journals and cultural supplements. He was given various awards during his lifetime, including the Premio Reina Sofía de Poesía Iberoamericana, and the Premio Miguel de Cervantes, both in 2009. He died in Mexico City on January 26, 2014.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Materials in the "Diaries and Journals" file group (boxes B-001261 to B-001268) are restricted for a period of five years, until 2024, as requested by Cristina Pacheco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file group consists of handwritten notebooks in which Pacheco appears to have recorded draft iterations of his writings, including poems, short stories, ideas, references to other writers, miscellaneous notes, course work, and other information related to his creative process. Some of the notebooks contain dated entries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Materials in the "Diaries and Journals" file group (boxes B-001261 to B-001268) are restricted for a period of five years, until 2024, as requested by Cristina Pacheco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 1 contains four notebooks from CUM (Centro Universitario México) titled "Cuaderno de Historial Universal," "Cuaderno de México," "Cuaderno de Moral", respectively, with one notebook being untitled, and primarily contain notes and playscripts, including "La estrella de oro," "El pasado lo guardan las arañas," and "La situación y los sueños".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file group consists of diaries and journals containing handwritten dated entries documenting Pacheco's daily activities, observations, opinions, and miscellaneous notes and writings. A few of the diaries contain photographs and other items laid-in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 1 contains a diary (1955) which includes black-and-white photographs laid-in, including portraits of Pacheco and other family members. The photographs are dated between 1956-1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file group includes drafts, excerpts, addenda, and final versions of various writings by Pacheco, including poetry, short stories, scripts, screenplays, essays, articles, translations, and others. Also included are writings by other authors, including translations of Pacheco's works. A large number of writings were undated, untitled, unattributed, and in many cases, drafts and fragments mixed together, which were impossible to separate and identify given the disorganized state of the material upon receipt.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Materials in the "Diaries and Journals" file group (boxes B-001261 to B-001268) are restricted for a period of five years, until 2024, as requested by Cristina Pacheco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes handwritten, typewritten, and print out manuscripts of Pacheco's poetry. Some of these writings contain handwritten corrections and annotations. Given the disorganized state of the material upon receipt in the repository, a large number of the poems have been placed in folders labeled as, "Miscellaneous", and it might be the case that some of these writings are not poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains one of the first poems written by Pacheco, and dedicated to his mother, for which he was awarded a prize in school in Mother's Day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file group consists of correspondence from various colleagues, publishers, family, and friends. Frequent and notable names found throughout the correspondence include Octavio Paz, Juan Vicente Melo, Carlos Fuentes, José Miguel Oviedo, Sergio Galindo, Félix Grande, Guillermo Cabrera Infante, Homero Aridjis, Carlos Monsivaís, Rosario Castellanos, José Bianco, Vicente Rojo, Hugo J. Verani (University of California, Davis), Saúl Sosnowski (University of Maryland at College Park), Juan Armando Epple (University of Oregon), Bruno Arcudi (State University of New York at Buffalo), Manuel Andújar (Alianza Editorial), Mario Muchnik (Muchnik Editores and Ariel/Seix Barral Editoriales), Fernando Vidal Buzzi (Editorial Sudamericana), and many others. Given the disorganized state of the material upon receipt in the repository, the correspondence has been arranged chronologically (by decades), and only the correspondence that arrived in groupings or was easily identified has been separated, including that of Octavio Paz, Juan Vicente Melo, Carlos Fuentes, José Miguel Oviedo, Sergio Galindo, Bruno Arcudi, and the family correspondence, chiefly Pacheco´s wife, daughters, and mother.
Additional description of names identified throughtout the correspondence was provided by PU gradudate student, Miguel Domínguez.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes chiefly photographs of José Emilio Pacheco with friends and attending lectures/talks. Other photographs include Cristina Pacheco with Marcela Lombardo (December 1993), and an unidentified photograph of possibly a family member. Most of the photographs are undated. Also included is an idenfication card with Pacheco´s photograph from I.N.A.H. (Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia).

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: For preservation reasons, original analog and digital media may not be read or played back in the reading room. Users may visually inspect physical media, but may not remove it from its enclosure. All analog audiovisual media must be digitized to preservation-quality standards prior to use. Patrons may request digital copies of original analog media, but will be responsible for the cost of digital conversion, payable in advance. Turn-around time for such requests will depend on the size and scope of the project. Requests should be directed to Public Services staff.
